question_list.author: Richard English
question_list.text:
Some folks might think cranberry glass
Is for fruit of the cranberry class.
But it's glass of deep red,
With a gold sheen, and said
To be sought by the English top brass.
question_list.question: What is sought by the English top brass?

question_list.author: SheilaB
question_list.text:
Uncle Wayne always gives me a pain.
His ideas are vain and inane.
He's both asinine (fatuous)
And a gas bag who's flatuous.
I treat the old fool with disdain.
question_list.question: What is wrong with Uncle Wayne's ideas?
question_list.answer: Uncle Wayne's ideas are vain and inane.
alternate_answers:
Uncle Wayne's ideas are considered vain and inane,
He's both asinine and flatuous, causing disdain.

Based on the limerick, there are a few things wrong with Uncle Wayne's ideas:

1. They are described as "vain and inane" - meaning they are empty, worthless, and foolish.

2. He is characterized as being "asinine" - which means stupid or foolish. 

3. He is also described as being a "gas bag" who is "flatuous" - implying his ideas are full of hot air and empty rhetoric.

4. The narrator treats Uncle Wayne with "disdain" - showing a strong dislike and lack of respect for his ideas.

Overall, the limerick portrays Uncle Wayne's ideas as being foolish, stupid, and unworthy of serious consideration. The narrator clearly has a very negative view of his uncle's thought processes and opinions.

question_list.author: proof
question_list.text:
Have a car and my clothes without fail
Outside of this old county jail.
It has only one fence,
 Which does not make much sense,
So tomorrow I'll scale it and bail.
question_list.question: what about the county jail does not make much sense?
alternate_answers: The limerick about the county jail mentions a person who plans to scale the fence to escape the jail, which is not a typical or sensible way to leave a jail.

Based on the limerick, the detail that does not make much sense about the county jail is that it "has only one fence". The limerick suggests this is odd, implying a typical county jail would have more than one fence to help secure the facility and prevent inmates from escaping.

question_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
question_list.text:
Our most serious faces we don
As the blamestorming session goes on.
Someone died. Who's to blame?
The one person we name
Is a janitor's helper named Juan.
question_list.question: Who do they blame in the blamestorming session after someone dies?
alternate_answers:
Based on the limericks, it seems the person they blame in the blamestorming session after someone dies is often a scapegoat or someone undeserving of the blame. 

For example, one limerick mentions:

"Someone died. Who's to blame?
The one person we name
Is a janitor's helper named Juan."

This suggests that in the blamestorming session, they unfairly blame an innocent person, like the janitor's helper Juan, rather than finding the true cause of the death.

question_list.author: MikeAq
question_list.text:
Mr. Thistle, what's this all about?
All our rules you dismiss — baldly flout.
I have read your epistle;
It made my hairs bristle.
I'm blowing the whistle — you're out!
question_list.question: Does Mr. Thistle follow our rules?
alternate_answers: Mr. Thistle does not follow the rules consistently. He often disregards them without explanation or justification.

Based on the limericks provided, the question appears to be about the limerick that mentions "Mr. Thistle". The relevant limerick is:

"Mr. Thistle, what's this all about? 
All our rules you dismiss — baldly flout.
I have read your epistle;
It made my hairs bristle.
I'm blowing the whistle — you're out!"

This limerick suggests that Mr. Thistle does not follow the rules, as the speaker is blowing the whistle on him for dismissing and flouting the rules.

limerick_list.author: Michael Toalster and SusanL
limerick_list.text:
Sergeant Pepper's old boys always meet
To play drums in a house down the street.
Since they deafened their pad,
All their neighbours are glad:
Now they can't hear a sound from that beat.

limerick_list.author: James Dobson
limerick_list.text:
I'm their father—each youngster's a pearl.
Yet my culpatory wife's prone to hurl:
"It's your seed that I blame!
Every child is the same—
Girl, girl, girl, girl, girl, girl, girl, girl, girl."

limerick_list.author: OldFitzer
limerick_list.text:
An accepting bank? People may say
That sounds oxymoronic, but hey!
The time drafts they write
Are a regular sight
In commerce and trade every day.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Thinking marriage, with Amy beguiled,
He inquired if she carried his child.
He decided to fly
At her only reply:
Ambiguously silent, she smiled.

limerick_list.author: Jacqui Brown
limerick_list.text:
Types of drip pans? I know only two.
Some drippings have value to you.
Meat drippings make sauce,
But the foul drips we toss—
From a crankcase, a fridge, or a zoo.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
His TV set habitually blared,
As my neighbor was hearing-impaired,
But he claimed this contraption 'd
Make programs closed-captioned,
With titles for shows that were aired.

limerick_list.author: Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
Silken diaphane's woven with lots
Of transparent or colorful spots
Amid diaper work,
But its rhomboid weave's  [smirk]
Not that messy job, cleaning up tots.

limerick_list.author: Cuttlefish
limerick_list.text:
The biotechnologist moaned:
"How I long for the days when we cloned!
Now, all night and all day
I just splice DNA—
I've forgotten which genes which thing owned!"

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"Fix this photo of Moon in your mind.
She's the kid we've been ordered to find."
Some celebrity's brat
Is job one, and that's that.
To long hours of work I'm resigned.

limerick_list.author: Kirk Zurell
limerick_list.text:
Seems this auction sale lacks popularity.
"Who'll give twenty-five cents for this rarity?"
Though the lot's not that nice,
I will bid up the price
'Cause the proceeds are going to charity.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
One day in the mountain town Aspen,
I said to the girl I was graspin',
"You're moaning like sin,
Yet I'm not even in."
"This thin air is the reason I'm gaspin'."

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
It's half-time and we look at the score.
Seems that we have three goals to your four.
But there's hope for us yet:
Just one more goal to get,
Then we equalise. Damn! That's a draw!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I make alloys. I'm now in a pickle;
Supplies are reduced to a trickle.
The dealers in copper
Have all come a cropper—
No more can I make cupronickel.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
There's no heat since they turned off our gas,
And there's frost on the mirror, alas!
With our lips turning blue,
One thing's certainly true:
It's as cold as a welldigger's ass.

limerick_list.author: zqms
limerick_list.text:
I'm well off; I have all that I need.
But my brother has more; we've agreed
That he's better off. Now,
If you beat that somehow,
Then, in riches, you're best off indeed.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
There's a challenge that prickles your hair
If the enemy's lines you would dare
Reconnoitre to seek
Any points that are weak.
It's a voice saying, "Halt! Who goes there?!"

limerick_list.author: StephenGold
limerick_list.text:
Though I'm broadly supportive of God,
He can be a vexatious old sod.
Thanks to damnum fatale
My roof's in the valley,
And the car's in my bedroom. Most odd.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
I often eat comfort food.  Stress
Is the trigger to make me regress
To my childhood and make
What my mom used to bake.
Over time, my weight grew to excess.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
There were skaters renamed Frick and Frack.
There were famed Car Talk hosts  Click and Clack.
At the warehouse, we two
Who fill orders for you
Are so proud to be called Pick and Pack.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
A Parisian mineral master
Discovered about alabaster
That translucent lime,
When ground, is sublime
For mixing a castable plaster.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
She was French, we were sure, so we flew
France's tricolor flag and hove to
With our false flag a-waving.
They'd small chance of saving
Tea and silks from our buccaneer crew.

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel and Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
In Cuba, a tease known as Anna
Is eating a yellow banana.
That's a fruit with appeal
(A lascivious meal!).
All the men drive with zeal to Havana.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
You're a factionist, Jack, can't you see?
You cause schisms where none ought to be.
Oh, the troubles you start —
Your lies split groups apart —
All those fictions cause frictions, agree?

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
It's a count of our folks and their land
Undertaken each decade and planned
By the Bureau of Census.
The next one commences
In two-thousand-ten—close at hand.

limerick_list.author: D Frayer
limerick_list.text:
"No depth!" was her cause for rejection.
Now the painter applies, as correction,
A deepening haze
To obscure the eye's gaze.
He has learned atmospheric projection.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
When you find that your mission's aborted,
You are sure that your scheme has been thwarted.
All the plans that you made
Have been laid in the shade;
All the circuits of life have been shorted.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
North Atlantic? That's where you'll find codfish,
So common we don't think them odd fish,
But they're not seen a lot
Where it's arid and hot,
So they're not the prevailing Riyadh fish.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
I'm Glaswegian and sometimes I've found
Glasgow turns, after drink, round and round.
I'm a Glasgow-born chap
And relieved my mishap
Only happens (I'm old) on home ground!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The once-savvy teacher was flustered.
He hemmed, and he hawed, and he blustered.
He'd forgotten his chalk,
Lost the thread of his talk—
He can't cut it. He can't cut the mustard!

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
It was Petrograd, always, for her.
To the end, she wore garments of fur.
My babushka, last year,
Passed away — Grandma dear....
That image, may time never blur.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
You're seeking a word that is neat-o?
Take nitrile and prefix aceto-.
What was cyanide will
Be a solvent, but still,
If you drink it, your life is finito.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Foreign policy can be a killer, son.
Not a job for Steves Bannon or Miller, son.
Jared, be my first mate.
Helm our new ship of state.
I'll move Rex far away from the tiller, son.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
She said, "What are you getting at, Mike,
When you ask what positions I like?
Like in baseball, you mean?"
No, his thoughts were obscene.
The light dawned, so she said, "Take a hike!"

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Chapter seven created the sense
Of anxiety—swift and intense.
Never boring or pale
Is this cliff-hanging tale;
It is thrilling and filled with suspense.

limerick_list.author: Basingstoke
limerick_list.text:
A duck with no beak would still waddle.
A snail with no shell would still dawdle.
But take off the tail
From the duck or the snail,
And what you have left is acaudal.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
When I clerked at the High Court last week,
I was awed by its ancient mystique.
Then, impressed with myself,
I slipped files from a shelf.
Call a plumber; the Court's sprung a leak!

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
We're potatoes—we're cool and we're dry,
Piled in field storage (oversupply).
With a covering of soil,
And some straw, we won't spoil.
(In Yorkshire, this clamp is a pie.)

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
This old wedding gown's so finely made.
See the lace, all hand-stitched, and the braid
Weaving round every gem
At the foot of the hem?
Bet the tailor was handsomely paid!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Said a nurse, "He's a geosphere." Why?
On your knowledge of English rely.
Geo signifies "dirt."
Sphere means "ball," I assert.
You can see what she thinks of this guy.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
While rickets can make your bones weak
And pellagra discolor your cheek,
Acute beriberi
Can make you sick, very —
Of avitaminosis I speak.

limerick_list.author: Dr. Work
limerick_list.text:
Is lettuce a part of Greek salad?
It depends, although both ways are valid.
But for certain, it betta
Include olives and feta
And tomatoes—nice red ones, not pallid.

limerick_list.author: old dad
limerick_list.text:
I am utterly taken aback
By the manners you totally lack.
I shall enecate you.
Yes, this chain saw will do,
And the pieces I'll put in a sack.

limerick_list.author: David
limerick_list.text:
In the three-legged race, Mrs. Pegg
And the Headmaster tripped on a keg
That was rolled by a boy
Down the track to annoy —
Which it did, for they shattered their leg.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
They're called Bim Skala Bim. At their heart
(Both their name and their tunes), is an art
Known as ska to their fans.
They have no touring plans:
Geographically, now they're apart.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Our divorce was a messy affair
Where my ex cleaned me out, left me bare.
I was filled with such rage.
Now I live in a cage,
But at least I'll be getting the chair.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
At times, game-changers come with a force
That will radically alter our course.
New directions they give,
Which affects how we live,
Like my poverty after divorce.

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
A meteor needs many hours
To emaculate: see how she scours
The grime from her body
Till she shines like a hottie.
This occurs during meteor showers.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"How I wish every date who's a cutie
Had this trait: a devotion to duty.
I'd convince her to mate,
That it's duty, equate
It with fate."  "Mate, that line is a beauty!"

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I've tried very hard to determine
If our pastor's my true cousin german,
But he won't let me see
His full family tree—
So each Sunday I sulk at his sermon.

limerick_list.author: DenmarK
limerick_list.text:
We're the jet-set, the upper-class bracket,
Spending money abroad — we don't lack it.
Costa Brava looks nice, hon—
Blue seas to entice. Sun
And sangria sure cost a packet!

limerick_list.author: Chaiwallah
limerick_list.text:
I invested some cash in a plane
But the business went straight down the drain.
I bailed out very fast
But that bailout's my last,
As I'll never try flying again.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
If word A is defined as "word B,"
Which in turn is defined as "word C,"
And they go on to say
That word C is "word A,"
Then your source is the pits, you'd agree.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Nostalgic for love gone awry,
I had called her and asked, "One more try?"
I appealed to romance,
But she screamed, "Not a chance!"
And an antisentimental "Goodbye!"

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Conflagration! One's lost—it's the sitter.
So bag her; she's one crispy critter:
Charred beyond recognition,
ID'd by dentition.
Dark humor can shock and embitter.

limerick_list.author: Brian Cairns
limerick_list.text:
To hear spoken Azeri, yer man
Goes to Baku, in Azerbaijan.
He might as well seek it
Where more people speak it—
In neighbouring Northwest Iran.

limerick_list.author: Chaiwallah
limerick_list.text:
A randy old sloth up a tree
Met an ai from Shanghai, and when he
Got a look at her heinie—
He whispered, "Wo ai ni!"
And two three-toed sloths became three.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Build a pipeline? No way — it'll leak.
She wears fibers, 'cause leather's not chic.
And her glare of reproach
When I murdered that roach…
She's a humorless, firm eco freak.

limerick_list.author: birdbarf
limerick_list.text:
Their murderous scheme really worked:
Plied with drink, soon the victims were burked.
They'd be stuffed in a box
For the good Doctor Knox.
(If dissected, I'd surely be irked.)

limerick_list.author: Jeff Foster
limerick_list.text:
Grumbled Bigfoot, "Inform Robert Frost:
Taking less-traveled roads has a cost.
The people in town
Say I'm hard to pin down,
But, elusiveness? Dude, I'm just lost."

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
Biologists act as recorders;
Though life doesn't really have borders,
The critters beguile 'em
To tally and file 'em
In classes — collections of orders.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Dear Dentist,

It's time for my yearly
Appointment.  I love my teeth dearly,
But my head's unprepared;
To be honest, I'm scared!
Guess I'll see you next year.

Yours sincerely,

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
I was offered a "donative gift"
With no shred of linguistical thrift.
Tautological forms
Are now marketing norms,
So I'm flattered, but equally miffed.

limerick_list.author: John Wellington Wells
limerick_list.text:
Should you want to import some gazelle,
You must speak to the pronghorn cartel.
To improve on their prices,
I'd say my advice is
To claim that you hate how they smell.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The film was cerebral and arty,
Not made for the dope but the smarty.
It should have been called
Albert Einstein, Enthralled,
Not Unsupervised Teenager Party.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
On the Nile, you are likely to see a
Graceful sailboat. I'm sure you'll agree a
Lovely picture 'twill make,
If a snapshot you take
Of the boat that folks call dahabeeyah.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The ceratosaur: fast and carnivorous,
And extinct, like those others herbivorous.
This is lucky for me
Since it's clear he would be
Very likely computer-geekivorous.

limerick_list.author: Gravely
limerick_list.text:
Keep yer ensilage fresh, cain't you larn?
Now jis' look at them horses an' darn
Drunken cows. How they dodder
An' hiccup! Their fodder
Ferminted too long in the barn.

limerick_list.author: Gravely
limerick_list.text:
While discussing his likes and dislikes,
"Erpetology gives me the shikes,"
Quoth the cockney. "Indeed, 
Tell me oo'd feel the need
To be studyin' 'orn toads an' snikes!"

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
Lost my chequebook! I got on the phone:
This guy answered—a call centre (groan!)
In Lahore, but the gist
Of his English I missed.
Who needs chequebooks? I'm getting a loan!

limerick_list.author: Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
The museum's chock-full, heaven knows:
Learnèd folks trampling other folks' toes.
But the study that's mine
Is the sampling of wine.
(Tyre and Nineveh perished—wine grows.)

limerick_list.author: Brian Cairns
limerick_list.text:
Crossing Niagara Falls with a brolly
Is an action of consummate folly.
Yet Blondin succeeded,
By fear unimpeded,
And thought the experience jolly.

limerick_list.author: Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
Amphimacer's foot, like a smile,
Starts out high, stressed, and long as a mile.
Then it drops, unstressed, short
Like a whispered retort,
And winds up, stressed in widening style.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
She comes in with her whole entourage.
On her dress is an orchid corsage,
But the flowers can't hide
What swells up from inside
Of her deeply cut décolletage.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
So I says to my local GP,
"Doctor, doctor, I think I'm a tree!"
Says the doc, "I'll be brief—
Time to turn a new leaf."
Then he fashions a table from me.

limerick_list.author: GaZoom
limerick_list.text:
Some metal, your body won't mind it,
But lead? Get it out if you find it.
Just flush through with water
And know that you oughter
Include a chelator to bind it.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
On the playground, "I'm rubber, you're glue"
Returns all your insults to you.
"Back atcha" can spurn
Slighting scorn or return
"Lots of luck!" "You're the best!" or "Woo-hoo!"

limerick_list.author: Workshop
limerick_list.text:
"All righty now, folks, let's get started!",
The teacher said, ere we departed.
"You have pressure below,
So it's ready, set, go!"
And then off to the loo we all darted.

limerick_list.author: Egbert
limerick_list.text:
My new baby monitor's wizard,
An invaluable tool for my lizard.
I don't fear that I'm missing
Abdominal hissing
From that bit of trapped wind in his gizzard.

limerick_list.author: Dr. Work
limerick_list.text:
It is Eastertime—know what is tops?
Chocolate rabbits are back in the shops!
I will first eat the ears...
(To allay all your fears,
It is NOT a real bunny that hops.)

limerick_list.author: TrossL
limerick_list.text:
Bugging someone does not involve bugs,
No, not beetles nor earwigs nor slugs.
It makes folks you annoy
(By mere chance, or with joy)
Want to smack you and not give you hugs.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
An aristocrat climbed Brokeback Mount
And suggested an act. His guide frownt.
"I've done things that I hate,
But I'm telling you, mate,
I will never go down for the count."

limerick_list.author: a.groovymind
limerick_list.text:
Despite the 'good word' that he'd brought,
Now the missionary stewed in the pot;
For the cannibal chief,
Lacking Christian belief...
Assimilable?  Both had that thought!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
If you're playing the role of a tough,
And your voice has to sound really rough,
This technique I can teach:
If you asperate speech,
Thinking Bogart, you'll make it sound gruff.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Two nine-year-olds, sucking on Slurpees,
Were discussing the study of CERPIES
When, digressing, one said,
"Though they're things people dread,
You know canker sores aren't caused by herpes."

limerick_list.author: pöt
limerick_list.text:
Philipp Schwartzerdt, from Bretten he came,
And in later life grecized his name:
As Melanchthon we know him,
How do history books show him?
A reformer of Lutheran fame.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Kids deserve, if they study, good grades.
Sometimes heroes deserve big parades.
But your ignorant crack
About gays is off track.
Truly no one deserves to get AIDS.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
With the wind from astern, we espied
Behind us, the Gorgon, allied.
So we'd meet, we hauled sail
Edge-on to the gale
(Abackstays) that we might abide.

limerick_list.author: Cuttlefish
limerick_list.text:
"Big Louie", for giggles and chuckles,
Has a trick that he does with brass knuckles:
Just a thump on your skull
And your senses go dull,
As first one, then the other knee buckles.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
"That girl Shirl I won fairly and squarely,"
Said Curley, "admittedly barely."
"No ruses or tricks
Did I use — take your licks!
But for kicks, I'll share Shirley, but rarely."

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Aristarchus of Samos, first one
To say Earth made a path 'round the Sun,
Was  dismissed as just wrong
By the earth-centric throng.
His bold theory's now doubted by none.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
Milking cows is the job I like best
On my farm in Wisconsin's midwest.
While I dream about cheese,
I have udders to squeeze—
Dairy farming just makes me feel blessed.

limerick_list.author: Richard English
limerick_list.text:
The word gluish means "something like glue".
Glue sticks things so they won't undo.
It's used to repair
Things you really can't spare
And it makes them look almost brand new.

limerick_list.author: jojo
limerick_list.text:
Our mom's oil-and-vinegar cruet
Is shattered; we're sad now and rue it.
Its contents remain
As a big greasy stain
On the wall by Dad's head where she threw it.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
My sweet memories of dear Molly Windley
Still come back to me now, although dimly.
Though at school, really nice,
She had one gripping vice:
Sad to say she would "smoke like a chimley!"

limerick_list.author: hugh.adler and Jesse Frankovich
limerick_list.text:
Rachel's sour and unpleasant—a hater
Of all—thus, acidic I'd rate her. . .
Yet this test says that Rach
Has a basic pH—
What a poor acid-base indicator!

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
I'm not an adept chef or cook,
But some recipes I undertook
To cook turned out great—
Like the hot turkey plate,
Which I found in my cookery book!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The police chief declared, "I presume
Morton's corpse we must now disentomb,
As I think it was murder.
Someone killed this old birder
For chasing off loons with a broom."

limerick_list.author: Giorgio Coniglio
limerick_list.text:
Deer and buffalo play near your home?
Made of durable plastic and chrome,
Our Smart Garden Gnome sprays
Roaming wildlife that strays,
Shooting targeted pepper-spray foam.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
"Freeze and don't move a muscle!  Stand still,"
Yelled a guard, "or I'll shoot you to kill!"
Thought the motionless felon,
"This itch is pure hell, 'n'
Not scratching takes all of my will."

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
By refusing the drugs, I'm ascetic—
Not numb to an art that's cosmetic.
The surgical flair
That I'll witness in there
In a sense will become an aesthetic.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Two corvids in combat I saw,
In an argument over some straw;
And I heard their loud caws
As this pair of young daws
Were debating the avian law.

limerick_list.author: Graham Lester
limerick_list.text:
Bewick's swans will stay mated for life,
Just a cob and his trouble and strife:
Unrepentant romantics,
Swans eschew kinky antics
(Back in Sparta, though, rumors were rife).

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I feel low — in a blues state. I'm sad
Since I live in a red state.  That's bad.
I'm depressed and I'm grumpy, 'n'
Pity my Trumpian
Friends, unaware they've been had.

limerick_list.author: Nitelaf
limerick_list.text:
You've no gown for the ball, so you're blue?
Got no carriage, and nary a shoe?
Well, your lot's not so tragic.
I'll help you—with magic!
Now... Bibbidi-Bobbidi-Boo!

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
An essential computer mouse trick:
Press the button twice fast, double-click.
This double depression
In rapid succession
Instead of just one click is slick.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
These old clothes have no monetary worth,
But this get up has cost me the earth,
As I look like a pig
In pink trousers — too big,
And a coat that increases my girth.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
His comebacker cracked off my knee
As its speed was too rapid for me.
I can't run like before,
'Cause my knee's always  sore.
Guess  our farm club's the next team I'll see.

limerick_list.author: Mad Kane
limerick_list.text:
A pair rather chintzy with cash
Often hosted an odd foursome bash.
When the pizza man rang,
"Give me twenty," they sang
To their guests—which accounts for their stash.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
My golf game last week was first rate.
I had fired a smooth 68.
I was crushed to the core
Later on, though. My score
On the back nine was not all that great.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
The girls' fearfulness showed that black night.
Their scared eyes opened wide, filled with fright.
The vile witch raised their hackles
With piercing cold cackles
And shrieks of unfettered delight.

limerick_list.author: Graham Lester
limerick_list.text:
We once had a tomcat named Liam,
And goldfish—he sure loved to see 'em!
Although he just purred,
We all quickly inferred
That his motto was this: carpe diem.

limerick_list.author: Scott Campisi
limerick_list.text:
The quarterback's calling it quits
'Cause his linemen and backs are the pits.
"The safeties surround me,
The linebackers pound me—
My blockers can't pick up the blitz!"

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
I came out.  I'm no longer a liar.
Now I'm camping it up.  Some inquire
Of the swish in my walk,
And the lisp in my talk,
And my voice being two octaves higher.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Sgt. Mayfield is in the latrine,
The result of some noxious cuisine.
Tainted clams overseas
Brought the man to his knees,
His appearance decidedly green.

limerick_list.author: oneslowtyper
limerick_list.text:
With a cramp in my biceps femoris,
I kicked out my leg, like Chuck Norris.
The cops were a pain,
As I tried to explain
Why I kicked that old lady Dolores.

limerick_list.author: David
limerick_list.text:
There was once a failed fakir from Seoul
Who applied rather hotly for dole,
For despite risk of burning,
He'd tested a yearning
To sleep on his bed of hot coal.

limerick_list.author: Ulfras and mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
These two golfers walk into a bar
For a shot and perhaps a cigar.
One's a pro, one's a vicar,
They went to drink liquor—
And now they're both way over par.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
He was valiantly trying to push
Through the dense Amazonian bush.
Now, we're holding his wake
'Cause a  bushmaster snake
Put its venomous fangs in his tush.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
You will find the hypophysis gland
And its adeno- lobe can command
The rate that we grow
(Through its endocrine flow)
Even more than the hamburger stand.

limerick_list.author: creelbm
limerick_list.text:
Vampire Bob fears cuisine from the Thai;
Pungent garlic their cooks like to fry.
Those cloves give him the willies,
Not the freaking hot chilies.
He's an alliumphobic bat guy.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
My brothers commoved me to streak
Down sorority row late last week.
They exhorted me, "Go!"
Now the sisters all know
I'm the Deke with the small, um, physique.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Cousin Ruth took the role of a sleuth
As she searched for the Fountain of Youth.
It's a mythical source
Of the magical force
That can keep us all youthful, in truth.

limerick_list.author: Ritepath
limerick_list.text:
My iPod is gone — I'm annoyed.
It fell in a well, down a void.
It's now a deperdit.
Precisely the word, it
Means "that which is lost or destroyed".

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
When we fight about ethics with Mary,
Her concepts of virtue may vary.
Devil's advocate? Heck!
She's a pain in the neck.
Her positions are always contrary.

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
In Brooklyn, some young nouveaux riches
Have found order, vocation, a niche.
In a setting that's cloistral,
They teach us, "The foist rule:
Don't talk about Monk Club. Capiche?"

limerick_list.author: SusanL
limerick_list.text:
On the cruise ship she's quite the converser,
Which aids in her role as precursor.
She can chatter away
On events of the day
Or the jobs of the captain or purser.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
The craft service puts out the snacks,
Bottled water and cold cuts in stacks.
So performers and crew
Have their cake, eat it too,
While the dolly grips lay some more tracks.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"I'm in search of a good magazine."
"They are sold in the upstairs canteen.
Use the entresol door
(Just between the first floor
And the second)—the store's mezzanine."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
What's a D-ring? When lately I mended
My work-clothes, the outcome was splendid;
I worked out a glitch
With this gizmo, from which
My overalls' straps were suspended.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
People call dishes china (don't you?)
'Cause they once came from China, it's true.
Now from T-shirts to teas,
So much stuff is Chinese,
Seems we wear, eat, and watch china too.

limerick_list.author: zqms
limerick_list.text:
"Your gashed cheek must be stitched, I'm afraid.
Did you shave with an extra-sharp blade?"
"Not at all, Doc; at work
I stood next to this jerk
Who got hiccups while using a spade."

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
Jason's ship, partly built by Athena,
Argo Navis would haunt the marina.
Now it hovers in pieces
Like glittering fleeces:
The Sail, and the Poop, and Carina.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
I asked Jan if she relished hot-tubbing.
She sure did. So her back I was scrubbing
When her husband came home,
Pushed my head in the foam,
And then thrashed me. I got a good drubbing.

limerick_list.author: Dr. Work
limerick_list.text:
A traveler on business attending
A trade show on merchandise vending
Each night went out boozing.
His job he's now losing,
For expense-account overextending.

limerick_list.author: Chuck Folkers
limerick_list.text:
My dear lady, I fear I will snap
If you don't shut your yammering trap.
Kindly silence your maw,
Your kisser, your jaw,
Your geggie, your pie-hole, your yap!

limerick_list.author: Bill Middleton
limerick_list.text:
There once was a chemist named Bill
Who turned water to gas with a pill.
He filled up his car,
But he didn't get far
'Cause his car would go only downhill.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
I resolved my old image I'd scotch
With a makeover, carve a new notch.
So silk Y-fronts I wore
But I got rather sore:
The elastic was chafing my crotch.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
He's at one with himself, his contentedness
A result of his focus and centredness;
But emotional oneness
Removes all the funness
Of acting with utter dementedness.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
If you live off the land, life is cruel
In the southwest U.S., but a jewel
Of a plant, I'm assured,
Is the buffalo gourd,
As its seeds yield an oil good for fuel.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
I'm no renter, I'm looking to buy land
And declare to the world, "This is my land."
Bishop Rock has appeal
As a homestead surreal:
It is known as the world's smallest island.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
The Essenes were a small Jewish sect
Who were minded to try to effect
A communal life noted
For living devoted
To values they wished to reflect.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Yes, I often run late, my dear friend,
And I do have some emails to send
Plus some clients I'm seeing,
But still, all things being —
Um — equal, I'm bucking the trend.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
At times it ain't nuanced or subtle
Deciding 'tween neighbors just what'll
Determine the bounds
Of their land and surrounds.
They can follow the line of abuttal.

limerick_list.author: Brent Annable
limerick_list.text:
"Please be careful," she said, "with my hair!
It's quite fragile, so treat it with care."
"Don't be silly!" I said,
And poured dye on her head.
I was wrong: now there's nothing much there.

limerick_list.author: jexia
limerick_list.text:
Mum sent me to college to wed.
"Get a bachelor—a rich one!" she said.
I studied computers
(And first-person shooters)
And Bachelor-hunted instead!

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
While asleep, Samuel heard the Lord's plea.
He woke Eli:  "What wish you of me?"
"You've been summoned, of course,
But you've got the wrong source.
Listen up, or get caller ID."

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
'Til enrolling in cookery class,
All your cooking had tasted like ass.
Now your great-tasting beans,
Based on vegan cuisines,
Mean you're finally cooking with gas!

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Though her plantings would often succumb,
Jean would boast of her awesome green thumb.
She was no garden queen,
As her thumb had gangrene —
Much too dumb to raise plums or a mum.

limerick_list.author: Charles Silliman
limerick_list.text:
A man from near Lago Maggiore
Made salad like none seen before.  A
Cardini by name
Achieved worldly acclaim
For his Caesar, the taste we adore, eh?

limerick_list.author: hwindle
limerick_list.text:
The congressional farm bill debate
Makes Big Ag use its lobbying weight
For more corporate wealth,
Not the safety and health
Of small farmers or what's on our plate.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
I'm chirurgeonly trained; my C.V.
Says "Cornell," "neurosurgeon," "M.D."
Since the price I command
For each slice is  a grand,
I throw cutting remarks in for free.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
"Scrimp and save.  It will pay in the end,"
Said my dad.  "Frugal living's your friend.
The less buying exceeds
Just your day-to-day needs,
The less time caught in want you will spend."

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Farmer Johnson's no longer around
Since his methods were clearly unsound.
A new fish farm he bought,
But it all came to naught
When the first time he plowed it he drowned.

limerick_list.author: Andrew Burnet
limerick_list.text:
The food's greasy, the staff are right nippy.
What the hell though—let's go for a chippie!
We know that it's sinful,
But we've had a skinful.
(Next morning, we're feeling quite gyppy.)

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Someone asked me today, "Are you gay?"
I am NOT into dudes!  What the hey!
My comeback was snappy:
"Yes, just when I'm happy."
Then I merrily went on my way.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
The Sorbonne is still angry at me
For pelting the chancellor with brie
At my doctoral aulic.
It's best not to frolic
When gathering up your degree.

limerick_list.author: jojo
limerick_list.text:
A languorous fellow named Phil,
By a doctor was given a pill
Which produced a proclivity
To frenzied activity
In listless folk lacking the will.

limerick_list.author: StephenGold
limerick_list.text:
Though the citizenry did have their say
When they went to the ballot that day,
And preferred Gore to Bush,
Hell, when shove came to push,
The decision went quite the wrong way.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
"Gadzooks!" cried St George from his horse.
"That dragon displays no remorse!
I'm amazed — that I am! —
That he's eaten a lamb ...
And a princess, it seems, is next course!"

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The word droven looks odd; that's a given.
It's an old-fashioned word meaning "driven."
"Obsolete!," linguists shout
At this word. "Throw it out!"
(Have I strove to define it, or striven?)

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The explorer was known for his daring
And for personal safety not caring.
His great pluck, you'll allow,
Is no good to him now.
He's a dinner some leopards are sharing.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
As a rule, you will reap what you sow,
And that could return pleasure or woe.
But with every new drill
And each newly learned skill
You've another string strung to your bow.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
In Oman, Stella saw a young fellah
Who while laboring sang a cappella.
As his shovel was  swingin',
He warbled: "I'm singin'
In the rain!" She said "Where's his umbrella?".

limerick_list.author: Bill LaVern Kalles
limerick_list.text:
You trust Newsweek alone? How exclusive!
Now your faith in Obama's delusive.
He's expanding the war,
And he spends four times more
Than George Bush, who was power-abusive.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
A penitent blackshirt from Kiel
Said, "The uniforms held great appeal,
So I joined the SS,
But now sadly confess
That their deeds made humanity reel."

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
As a lad, I got bashed and assailed;
Every bully I battled prevailed.
Have you heard of the child
Who was born to be wild?
I'm the kid who was born to be whaled.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
Someone knocked at her door and then went,
So she looked out to see what it meant;
His big bunch of flowers
Adds bloom to his powers
Through beauty and love, heaven scent.

limerick_list.author: Duncan Stevens
limerick_list.text:
I'm a rather strange farmer, I know,
'Cause I link the plants' stalks as they grow:
Bind the crops in their bed
With a needle and thread;
Next fall I will reap what I sew.

limerick_list.author: Jesse Frankovich
limerick_list.text:
Baking powder has leavening power.
To stay dry, it contains starch or flour.
But the acid and base
Do the work in this case,
And give rise to delights to devour.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
What is used for closed-captions or crawl
Is a chyron.  I'm sure that that's all
That your broadcast will need
To display text they feed —
And drive viewers like me up a wall.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I fear my statistics are skewed,
As the birth rate Lew gave me was crude.
Is it, then, not correct?
I would like to object
But I'd hate to appear to be rude!

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
Said God, "On your belly you'll crawl,"
To those treacherous snakes; of them all,
It might well have been
In His mind, at the scene,
That an elapid triggered the Fall.

limerick_list.author: Steve Andersen
limerick_list.text:
The students are so argumentive,
What's needed is action preventive.
They don't need to fight
To settle what's right.
They really should be more inventive.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
The color within cannot hide;
When gypsum is chemically dried
It's anhydrite, with hue
Of a pale lilac blue,
Renamed angelite, New Agers' pride.

limerick_list.author: Mark Mironer
limerick_list.text:
They applied ugly torture devices
Without any thought what the price is.
With each question they posed,
The detainee was hosed
As the lawmen performed anacrisis.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
The Chinook and the coho? Terrific.
They live in the northeast Pacific.
They're salmon, related;
The difference is stated:
Chinook have some black parts specific.

limerick_list.author: alan meyer
limerick_list.text:
My doctor looked grim as she spoke:
"You're obese, out of shape, and you smoke.
The result of all these —
Coronary disease.
Change your lifestyle, or die.  It's no joke."

limerick_list.author: timon
limerick_list.text:
Caught stealing to feed my addictions,
In court I'll devise clever fictions,
Which is easy for me:
I've the courage, you see,
Of my (numerous prior) convictions.

limerick_list.author: David
limerick_list.text:
When you use the word amphichromatic,
Few laymen feel over-ecstatic.
To them it's all Greek
(Which it is) that you speak.
Say "having two hues" — it's emphatic.

limerick_list.author: GalFisk
limerick_list.text:
It's haphazard and random, the way
That I get through my life. Every day
Is quite planless, as such.
So I don't know how much
I will eat, work or sleep, earn or pay.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Caveman Dana designed novel traps
To catch dinosaurs, wondered perhaps
If his wooden contraptions
Would suffer collapsions—
That is: would the damned things collapse?

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I am tired of being harassed, Lee.
Your attempts to seduce me are ghastly.
In my faith I'm secure
From your motives impure;
To my Christian beliefs I'm tied fastly.

limerick_list.author: Workshop
limerick_list.text:
In the boat club next door, we do rowing,
Provided the wind is not blowing
Too strongly. That's crazy?
But no, our group's lazy
And simply do not like hard going.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
When complete indecision attacks,
You consider by weighing the facts,
And start wondering too,
As in, "What would I do
If my tum could stay flat fed on snacks?"

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Part of Darwin's bizarre archivalia:
Cartoons showing cebocephalia—
Darwin drawn to look funky,
His face like a monkey.
(Not displayed, glad to say: genitalia.)

limerick_list.author: zqms
limerick_list.text:
"Go and ask for her number," said John.
"She'll just laugh, and I think she's long gone."
"She's right there! Try 'hello'.
She can't say more than 'no'."
"I'm afraid. Please stop egging me on."

limerick_list.author: R. A. Shortfellow
limerick_list.text:
A firebed's a layer that's burning,
Like below a big boiler that's turning
Cold water to hot,
And it's also a lot
Like my heart when some lass keeps it yearning.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I had nothing to eat. Who could blame me
When I ate my dead pets, Marv and Amy?
I wept, but then, starvin',
Ate Amy, then Marvin.
They tasted like game, i.e., gamey.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Milk is best if it's used by the date
On the carton.  This morning at 8,
I went down for a cup,
But I nearly threw up.
Seems I made me some cafe au late.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
See the hop plant, a typical bine:
Around a support stems entwine;
No tendrils appear,
And no suckers adhere—
For such structures define a true vine.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The passengers airside are "clean,"
Having passed the security screen.
Those landside, however,
Are "dirty," so never
Relax your surveillance—stay keen.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
An aircraftman, Hank, drew a blank,
When borrowing funds from a bank.
He was told, "We're afraid
That you're much too low-paid."
(In the airforce, he's lowest in rank.)

limerick_list.author: zqms
limerick_list.text:
Female anglerfish often can use
Dorsal light-giving rods to bemuse
Either males as a mate,
Or prey with this bait —
Maybe both though; they'd then need to choose.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
While playing a gig in Aruba
And combining my fondness for scuba,
I sang underwater
With Neptune's fair daughter,
Accomp'nied by a blowfish on tuba.

limerick_list.author: Lee Raven
limerick_list.text:
"To precipitate alkali salt,"
Said my chemistry lecturer, Walt,
"Mix an acid and base.
When the atoms embrace,
The salt is then left by default."

limerick_list.author: Robert Holland
limerick_list.text:
A lion's an arrogant beast;
His manners are crude, but, at least,
Retromingent is he
When he pleases to pee.
You're in trouble behind at a feast.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Those swimmers would never have drowned
Had the lifeguard kept looking around
Circumspectly, with care,
As she perched on her chair,
Getting beautifully, evenly browned.

limerick_list.author: art bates
limerick_list.text:
In the eyes of beholders you'll find
There's a great gaping difference of mind
'Tween what's art and what's junk,
What's sublime and what stunk,
But don't argue with either—they're blind.

limerick_list.author: Robert Holland
limerick_list.text:
Be Prepared is a creed that sounds geeky.
It is cooler today to be sneaky.
To a Boy Scout, his word
Must be honored. "Absurd!"
Sneer his classmates. "Your morals are freaky!"

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
So funny's the joke that you told,
I died laughing.  The floor's where I rolled.
I guffawed so damn much
And so hard, it was such
That my bladder could not be controlled.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Mortality curbs the capacity
To cling to life's twig with tenacity.
Flowers fade and leaves fall,
Tempus fugit withal.
Fleeting beauty's soon vanquished: fugacity.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Our big blast scene needs natural gas.
Folks at Equity won't let it pass.
Unapproved union shoots
Guarantee union suits.
We're on hold—what a pain in the ass!

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Body politic seems to apply
To us organized folks who rely
On those cunning and cool
Politicians to rule.
But we're no body's fool, you and I.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses and Bill LaVern Kalles
limerick_list.text:
Desert locusts swarmed in, don't you know?
Ate each section, each field, and each row.
They were eighth on the plagues list
(Saw Egypt on craigslist) —
The tenth made the Pharaoh let go.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
The word watergate once meant a gate
Related to water; but wait…
Seems its suffix (duh, -gate)
Had a strange twist of fate;
To a scandal most -gate words relate.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The "Mad Bomber" assumptions were tested:
When Metesky at last, was arrested,
He got dressed in his best,
Just as Brussel had guessed,
In a suit that was—yes—double-breasted.

limerick_list.author: Charles Silliman
limerick_list.text:
In comic strips, stories are drawn
About made-up and real goings-on.
This sequential art style
Has been 'round a great while,
In some form, since the time of man's dawn.

limerick_list.author: limarico
limerick_list.text:
We can't comment on who is to blame
'Cause that's classified — yes, that's a shame!
That's unless you can show
You have clearance to know
What the government does in your name.

limerick_list.author: alkahuna
limerick_list.text:
In making a film, cast and crew
Get a call sheet designed to show who
Works each day on what scene,
When and where to convene...
How and why? Well, for that there's no clue.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
Once again I awake to the streaming
Sweet sunlight, which ends my night's dreaming.
It's my goal when I die
To meet God, riding high,
In my sleep, with my passengers screaming.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
When a shark goes out hunting alone
And its prey see it coming, they moan.
No attention is paid
That its skeleton's made
Out of cartilage, rather than bone.

limerick_list.author: Gravely
limerick_list.text:
Said the chimp to the newcomer, "You're
Like a cousin — your bloodlines are pure!
Come and take tea, inside."
The bonobo replied,
"How congenerous of you, I am sure."

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
I discovered some galls on a tree;
Found the insect name, using a key.
All recorded and dated
And published. Elated!
Happy cecidiologist, me.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Do you hanker for cheese? Need your fix?
Try one of these white farm cheese bricks.
It's made from the curd
Of skim milk. Take my word,
It's preferred by us hicks in the sticks.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Neighbors said the assailant was crazed.
And the victim? Surprised and amazed—
First he grabbed for her purse,
Raised his fist in a curse,
And then left her (what's worse) hurt and dazed.

limerick_list.author: John Young
limerick_list.text:
I'm just so avant-garde—it's my passion.
Once impeccably rouged, now I'm ashen.
For it ended in blows,
When Gok Wan stole my clothes—
You could say I'm a victim of fashion.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
The pod, whether pulse crop or weed,
Needs some dryness to rupture with speed.
Then it splits open wide
To discharge what's inside:
This dehiscence will scatter the seed.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
Back in earlier times, King Canute
Got involved in a tidal dispute.
And his courtiers cheered
Till their king disappeared.
When he surfaced, they all got the boot!

limerick_list.author: Jane Auerbach
limerick_list.text:
Stinks so bad you might call it ferocious,
That Limburger cheese smells atrocious.
But my five-year-old kid
(Whom I just can't forbid
A taste) likes it—she must be precocious.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Your position exposed — in distress?
Try an all-out, robust full-court press.
Dog their every damn move,
Watch your chances improve.
They'll back off, tend their wounds, reassess.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
This winter, for more than a week, a
Vacation I'll probably seek—a
Good climate, white beaches,
And high mountain reaches.
I'll find them in sweet Costa Rica.

limerick_list.author: geniuswaitress
limerick_list.text:
I'm told (though it sounds rather hokey)
That Americans call it the pokey,
Or slammer, or brig,
But who gives a fig?
Being English, I'm locked in the chokey.

limerick_list.author: hwindle
limerick_list.text:
"How I carried that torch," Troilus cried.
"But my flame, at her faithlessness, died.
When those lamps that burn grease
Contain nothing, they cease.
Ah! My cresset is oil-less," he sighed.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Adhered algae is fouling my yacht.
The crud's glued to my hull; it's near shot.
Add the barnacles, slime
And now tubeworms and grime—
My retirement is going to pot.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
For your boy, who consoled you, a dreidel.
For your mom, who made soup, a new leidel.
For your husband who swore
He'd stop seeing that whore,
What'll even the score? A greneidel!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
These traits that we deem evolutional
Our faculty finds attributional
(After careful inspection)
To nature's selection.
The concept's, for us, institutional.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Yes, she wore that red hat with the brim,
And the flowers, with ribbons as trim.
As a churchwoman, she
Looked to Sundays with glee.
She knew many a hymn (but no him).

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
The Friends of Distinction I'm praising
For "Going in Circles" and "Grazing
In the Grass" and a third
That the public preferred:
"Love or Let Me Be Lonely."  Amazing!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"I shoe horses," said farrier Sam
To his date. "Is that some sort of scam?"
The gal asked. "Something's funny.
You say you make money
By encouraging horses to scram?"

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
A head filled with nothing, they say,
Is in danger of drifting astray.
See—your braincase is full,
So that gravity's pull
Stops your cranium's sailing away.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
This new flapper style looks a bit odd,
But it flatters a thick girl's façade.
Yes, the drop-waist look's yummy
And swallows the tummy.
You're hot, Daisy—honest to God.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
She was deeply involved and engrossed
In the precepts of Emily Post:
Ladies don't cross their knees
At receptions or teas,
And they don't sop up gravy with toast.

limerick_list.author: Andrew Burnet
limerick_list.text:
Playing markets with other folks' cash,
I amassed a gargantuan stash,
A magnificent chievance.
Imagine my grievance:
I lost every bean in the crash.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
I worked in a card shop one summer,
A place called The Different Drummer.
As a hard-working chap,
I sold Hallmark-y crap,
All at minimum wage.  What a bummer!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Though I'm male, I have female-like hips:
Lush, provocative—likewise my lips.
"When all's said and done,
Avoid prison, my son."
This was one of my father's best tips.

limerick_list.author: Nitelaf
limerick_list.text:
Said the doctor, "My firm diagnosis
Is abdominal fibromatosis.
A tumor's the issue—
Not cancerous tissue,
But merely a type of fibrosis."

limerick_list.author: Jeff Foster
limerick_list.text:
Disappointment was brushed to the side
When a cowpoke's request was denied:
"I'm not fit, say the brass,
To make Cowboy First Class?
Hell,  I'll show 'em some cowpokin' pride!"

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
It arrived with today's network feed
With some copy for anchors to read:
A gold star of a story.
Now we share in the glory
Unearthed and dispersed like fresh seed.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
The farmer (a sportsman, no doubt)
Wouldn't ever go fishin' without
An atomic reactor
On top of his tractor—
He liked to go fission for trout.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Crimson is red with a  hint
Of deep pink, for a rosier tint.
It's the colour of kings'
Robes and carpets and things.
Red's to crimson what green is to mint.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
The old cop told his mate, "Hold your gab;
Or that snatcher will run to the lab
Of Doc Frankenstein. Grief
To the bold body thief!"
And those grabs grabbed the grabbable grab.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Jim approached his first date with timidity,
But he soon fell in love, with fervidlty
(With burning intensity).
His virgin propensity
Was to ask her to wed—with rapidity.

limerick_list.author: nevadaace
limerick_list.text:
The President yelled, "Get them now!
AAF! Are you deaf? Don't care how!"
See, the Army Air Forces
Are fighting war horses,
And foes just sent shots 'cross the bow.

limerick_list.author: Jesse Frankovich
limerick_list.text:
In the football Americans play,
The blockers will get in the way
Of the tacklers pursuing
The runner, who's doing
His best to break free from the fray.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Said his mother, "Please clean your room, Eddie."
"I will get to it, Mom, when I'm ready!"
Her response? Seeing red,
A left hook to the head.
(He's been at it now three hours steady.)

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
A causeuse is for two to confer.
But for some, it's to snuggle and purr.
It's a mini-settee
Too congested for three,
But it suits the amour connoisseur.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Aluminiform: what does it mean?
"Of the form of an alum," I'd seen.
So I googled around
For this word, and I found
That there's nothing beyond that to glean.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
How can I differentiate James
From Hamish, his twin, when their names
Are, like them, so alike?
(Why can't one be called Spike,
As their looks are the samest of sames?)

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Says Doc Kaiser, my dental adviser,
"All your cuspids and every incisor,
Both above and beneath,
Are what's called cutting teeth."
Now while biting my rye bread, I'm wiser.

limerick_list.author: Phyl Reinhard and Jane Auerbach
limerick_list.text:
A Baltimore poet named Poe
Once raved about ravens, you know?
So a Baltimore team
Took their name in esteem.
As an homage, it seemed apropos.

limerick_list.author: Andrew Burnet
limerick_list.text:
As a badger who looks like a ferret,
I can match either creature for merit.
Plus, should either die out,
Thanks to famine or drought,
I'm the cousin who stands to inherit.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
"You can keep what you've got, no dispute.
That's a promise, a firm absolute.
End of story."  We liked
What we had.  With rates spiked,
We get socked.  Can we give him the boot?

limerick_list.author: StephenGold
limerick_list.text:
Now the cha-cha, a dance so latino,
Should be shunned if you've drunk too much vino.
Try to sashay with class
And you land on your ass:
My dear wife and I tried it—now we know!

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
I went fishing, but soon felt deflated —
Not a bite, though I'd patiently waited.
To avoid getting thinner,
I ate worms for my dinner,
And sat there, forlorn, with breath baited.

limerick_list.author: Kevin
limerick_list.text:
Attempting to sit Abitur
Was not a success, to be sure,
And it still is a mystery
How I passed (flunking history,
And French being far from à jour).

limerick_list.author: Son of Baltimore
limerick_list.text:
A fisherman loaded his dhow
With more weight than the craft would allow.
A passerby laughed,
"Hey, you're showing your aft!
You've got much too much bait in the bow."

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The cottier's life wasn't pleasant,
As he toiled on the land like a peasant.
Or he'd rent a small farm,
Having bid for the charm
Of supporting a lord shooting pheasant.

limerick_list.author: SusanL
limerick_list.text:
Pete and Henry are studyin' hard
To be farmers of highest regard.
But their eyes often stray,
When they're taught to make hay,
To those cow college girls in the yard.

limerick_list.author: Carl Lands
limerick_list.text:
Some are sure that events follow laws—
That effect follows cause without pause.
They require forbearance;
It's clear they're not parents:
They cannot believe just because.

limerick_list.author: Tom Foolery
limerick_list.text:
To explain in a word that apparel
Just means "clothing" is truthful but sterile.
Rather, why not provide
An example, a guide?
What'll do this? Whatever you wear'll.

limerick_list.author: Bluebelle and SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
An unhappy young lady from Ware—
"From where?" "It's in Hertfordshire... there!"—
Felt so lost she was hopeless
And helpless, and copeless.
Despairful, this dame didn't care.

limerick_list.author: sigg
limerick_list.text:
The right-hander pitched with a grunt
As I squared with the bat out in front.
I think nothing is funner
Than moving a runner
By perfectly placing a bunt.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
His caress, like the silkiest lotion
On her skin, fires the loving emotion
That he longs to confess;
But no words can express
The full depth of his utter devotion.

limerick_list.author: Chaiwallah
limerick_list.text:
Major Wilmer went barmy, poor chap,
And we all put it down to the clap.
But it seems the poor sod
Really thought he was God:
A bad case of the old Balkan tap.

limerick_list.author: StephenGold
limerick_list.text:
A gullible girl named Fiona
Bought a Mini, "Just one careful owner",
From a salesman whose leer
Should have been a clear steer
That his fides were mala, not bona.

limerick_list.author: Graham Lester
limerick_list.text:
Do you think that some swats with my brolly would
Make them less Anglophobic in Hollywood?
Must their rogues all be Brits?
Still, I think that such hits
Would not hurt like withholding my lolly would.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
My driver's a dimwit who's brash,
And in traffic he's reckless and rash.
On the left, traffic's slow,
So I tell this dumb Joe:
"Use the right lane. Just edge in, and—" CRASH!

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
They've had 50-plus years of futility.
They're lacking in bouncebackability.
Return to good form?
Good at sucking's the norm
On the football field.  Oh, the humility!

limerick_list.author: BobHale
limerick_list.text:
Sitting comfortably? Then I'll begin.
Open mouth, take a plum, put it in.
Every vowel? It's rounded.
Every consonant? Sounded.
Speak BBC English, and win!

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Cuneated means "v-shaped," like wedges.
That gave cavemen superior edges.
There's less to be feared
Bearing arms engineered —
Spears and axes beat primitive sledges.

limerick_list.author: BobfromThirsk
limerick_list.text:
It bain't a right cleverish notion
When thinking of crossing the ocean
To have bathtubs in mind
Of the cast-iron kind—
'Cause they sail with a downwardish motion.

limerick_list.author: cauliflower
limerick_list.text:
We worship in churches, I've read,
'Cos religions are mostly man-led.
But if women held sway
We would probably pray
In sanctified shoe shops instead.

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
An amen: it'll come at the close
Of all prayers, or be uttered by those
Who are making a point,
Emphasized to anoint
An opinion that everyone knows.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
In the talent show, arguments tore
Through the judges, as acts took the floor.
When the 'ground-breaking choice'
Had an ear-splitting voice,
The whole nation was shocked to the core.

limerick_list.author: bearybp
limerick_list.text:
Bill Gladstone and Benny Disraeli
Would bicker in Parliament daily.
"We'll suffer no more o' ya!"
Roared Queen Victoria.
"THWACK!" went the royal shillelagh.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Got no word for it? Label it foo.
No one minds if the naming's untrue.
Your new app's got a glitch?
Create foos, scratch that itch.
Use a placeholder name. Muddle through.

text: This is a test to see how well you are paying attention. This text is a series of limericks. At the end of the list of limericks, there will be a question. The question will be about one of the limericks. Please answer the question as concisely as possible.
